sentence1: It so happened that Finn and his gigantic relatives were all working at the Giant's Causeway in order to make a bridge, or, what was still better, a good stout pad-road across to Scotland.
sentence2: Finn, who was very fond of his wife, Oonagh, took it into his head that he would go home and see how the poor woman got on in his absence.

sentence1: Finn, who was very fond of his wife, Oonagh, took it into his head that he would go home and see how the poor woman got on in his absence.
sentence2: So accordingly he pulled up a fir-tree, and after lopping off the roots and branches, made a walking-stick of it and set out on his way to Oonagh.

sentence1: So accordingly he pulled up a fir-tree, and after lopping off the roots and branches, made a walking-stick of it and set out on his way to Oonagh.
sentence2: There was at that time another giant, named Far Rua--some say he was Irish and some say he was Scotch--but whether Scotch or Irish, sorrow doubt of it but he was a targer.

sentence1: There was at that time another giant, named Far Rua--some say he was Irish and some say he was Scotch--but whether Scotch or Irish, sorrow doubt of it but he was a targer.
sentence2: No other giant of the day could stand before him.

sentence1: No other giant of the day could stand before him.
sentence2: Such was his strength that, when well vexed, he could give a stamp that shook the country about him.

sentence1: Such was his strength that, when well vexed, he could give a stamp that shook the country about him.
sentence2: The fame and name of him went far and near, and nothing in the shape of a man, it was said, had any chance with him in a fight.

sentence1: The fame and name of him went far and near, and nothing in the shape of a man, it was said, had any chance with him in a fight.
sentence2: Whether the story is true or not I cannot say, but the report went that by one blow of his fist he flattened a thunderbolt, and kept it in his pocket in the shape of a pancake to show to all his enemies when they were about to fight him.

sentence1: Whether the story is true or not I cannot say, but the report went that by one blow of his fist he flattened a thunderbolt, and kept it in his pocket in the shape of a pancake to show to all his enemies when they were about to fight him.
sentence2: Undoubtedly he had given every giant in Ireland a considerable beating, barring Finn M'Coul himself.

sentence1: Undoubtedly he had given every giant in Ireland a considerable beating, barring Finn M'Coul himself.
sentence2: He swore that he would never rest night or day, winter or summer, till he could serve Finn with the same sauce, if he could catch him.

sentence1: He swore that he would never rest night or day, winter or summer, till he could serve Finn with the same sauce, if he could catch him.
sentence2: Finn, however, had a strong disinclination to meet a giant who could make a young earthquake or flatten a thunderbolt when he was angry.

sentence1: Finn, however, had a strong disinclination to meet a giant who could make a young earthquake or flatten a thunderbolt when he was angry.
sentence2: Accordingly he kept dodging about from place to place--not much to his credit as a Trojan, to be sure--whenever he happened to get the hard word that Far Rua was on the scent of him.

sentence1: Accordingly he kept dodging about from place to place--not much to his credit as a Trojan, to be sure--whenever he happened to get the hard word that Far Rua was on the scent of him.
sentence2: And the long and the short of it was that he heard Far Rua was coming to the Causeway to have a trial of strength with him.

sentence1: And the long and the short of it was that he heard Far Rua was coming to the Causeway to have a trial of strength with him.
sentence2: He was, naturally enough, seized in consequence with a very warm and sudden fit of affection for his wife, who was delicate in her health, poor woman.

sentence1: He was, naturally enough, seized in consequence with a very warm and sudden fit of affection for his wife, who was delicate in her health, poor woman.
sentence2: She was leading, besides, a very lonely, uncomfortable life of it in his absence.

sentence1: She was leading, besides, a very lonely, uncomfortable life of it in his absence.
sentence2: "God save all here," said Finn good-humouredly, putting his honest face into his own door.

sentence1: "God save all here," said Finn good-humouredly, putting his honest face into his own door.
sentence2: "Faith," said Finn, "beautiful;

sentence1: "Faith," said Finn, "beautiful;
sentence2: Finn gave a short, good-humoured cough.

sentence1: Finn gave a short, good-humoured cough.
sentence2: He laughed most heartily to show her how much he was delighted that she made herself happy in his absence.

sentence1: He laughed most heartily to show her how much he was delighted that she made herself happy in his absence.
sentence2: "An' what brought you home so soon, Finn?"

sentence1: "An' what brought you home so soon, Finn?"
sentence2: "Why, avourneen," said Finn, putting in his answer in the proper way, "never the thing but the purest of love and affection for yourself.

sentence1: "Why, avourneen," said Finn, putting in his answer in the proper way, "never the thing but the purest of love and affection for yourself.
sentence2: Sure, you know that's truth, anyhow, Oonagh."

sentence1: Sure, you know that's truth, anyhow, Oonagh."
sentence2: Finn spent two or three happy days with Oonagh, and felt himself very comfortable considering the dread he had of Far Rua.

sentence1: Finn spent two or three happy days with Oonagh, and felt himself very comfortable considering the dread he had of Far Rua.
sentence2: This, however, grew upon him so much that his wife could not but perceive something lay on his mind which he kept altogether to himself.

sentence1: This, however, grew upon him so much that his wife could not but perceive something lay on his mind which he kept altogether to himself.
sentence2: Let a woman alone in the meantime for ferreting or wheedling a secret out of her good man when she wishes.

sentence1: Let a woman alone in the meantime for ferreting or wheedling a secret out of her good man when she wishes.
sentence2: "It's this Far Rua," said he, "that's troublin' me.

sentence2: When the fellow gets angry and begins to stamp he'll shake you a whole townland.

sentence1: When the fellow gets angry and begins to stamp he'll shake you a whole townland.
sentence2: It's well known that he can stop a thunderbolt, for he always carries one about with him in the shape of a pancake to show to anyone that might misdoubt it."

sentence1: It's well known that he can stop a thunderbolt, for he always carries one about with him in the shape of a pancake to show to anyone that might misdoubt it."
sentence2: As he spoke he clapped his thumb in his mouth, as he always did when he wanted to prophesy or to know anything.

sentence1: As he spoke he clapped his thumb in his mouth, as he always did when he wanted to prophesy or to know anything.
sentence2: "He's coming," said Finn.

sentence1: "He's coming," said Finn.
sentence2: "I see him below at Dungannon."

sentence1: "I see him below at Dungannon."
sentence2: "Far Rua," replied Finn, "and how to manage I don't know.

sentence1: "Far Rua," replied Finn, "and how to manage I don't know.
sentence2: If I run away I am disgraced, and I know that sooner or later I must meet him, for my thumb tells me so."

sentence1: If I run away I am disgraced, and I know that sooner or later I must meet him, for my thumb tells me so."
sentence2: "Don't be cast down," said Oonagh.

sentence1: "Don't be cast down," said Oonagh.
sentence2: "Depend on me, and, maybe, I'll bring you out of this scrape better than ever you could bring yourself."

sentence1: "Depend on me, and, maybe, I'll bring you out of this scrape better than ever you could bring yourself."
sentence2: This quieted Finn's heart very much, for he knew that Oonagh was hand-and-glove with the fairies.

sentence1: This quieted Finn's heart very much, for he knew that Oonagh was hand-and-glove with the fairies.
sentence2: If she was, however, she must have been a kind-hearted one, for by all accounts she never did anything but good in the neighbourhood.

sentence1: If she was, however, she must have been a kind-hearted one, for by all accounts she never did anything but good in the neighbourhood.
sentence2: Now, it so happened that Oonagh had a sister named Granua living opposite to them, on the very top of Cullamore, which I have mentioned already.

sentence1: Now, it so happened that Oonagh had a sister named Granua living opposite to them, on the very top of Cullamore, which I have mentioned already.
sentence2: Upon this occasion Oonagh resolved to consult her sister as to what was best to be done in the difficulty that surrounded them.

sentence1: Upon this occasion Oonagh resolved to consult her sister as to what was best to be done in the difficulty that surrounded them.
sentence2: "Granua," said she, "are you at home?"

sentence1: "Granua," said she, "are you at home?"
sentence2: "No," said the other, "I'm picking bilberries at Althadhawan" (the Devil's Glen).

sentence1: "No," said the other, "I'm picking bilberries at Althadhawan" (the Devil's Glen).
sentence2: "Well," said Oonagh, "go up to the top of Cullamore, look about you, and then tell us what you see."

sentence1: "Well," said Oonagh, "go up to the top of Cullamore, look about you, and then tell us what you see."
sentence2: "What do you see?"

sentence1: "What do you see?"
sentence2: asked the other.

sentence1: asked the other.
sentence2: exclaimed Granua, "I see the biggest giant that ever was known coming up from Dungannon."

sentence1: exclaimed Granua, "I see the biggest giant that ever was known coming up from Dungannon."
sentence2: "I'll call to him," she replied, "to come up to Cullamore and refresh himself, and maybe that will give you and Finn time to think of some plan to get yourselves out of the scrape.

sentence1: "I'll call to him," she replied, "to come up to Cullamore and refresh himself, and maybe that will give you and Finn time to think of some plan to get yourselves out of the scrape.
sentence2: But," she proceeded, "I'm short of butter, having in the house only half a dozen firkins, and as I'm to have a few giants and giantesses to spend the evenin' with me I'd feel thankful, Oonagh, if you'd throw me up fifteen or sixteen tubs, or the largest miscaun you've got, and you'll oblige me very much."

sentence1: But," she proceeded, "I'm short of butter, having in the house only half a dozen firkins, and as I'm to have a few giants and giantesses to spend the evenin' with me I'd feel thankful, Oonagh, if you'd throw me up fifteen or sixteen tubs, or the largest miscaun you've got, and you'll oblige me very much."
sentence2: "I'll do that with a heart and a half," replied Oonagh;

sentence1: "I'll do that with a heart and a half," replied Oonagh;
sentence2: "and, indeed, Granua, I feel myself under great obligations to you for your kindness in keeping him off us till we see what can be done;

sentence1: "and, indeed, Granua, I feel myself under great obligations to you for your kindness in keeping him off us till we see what can be done;
sentence2: for what would become of us all if anything happened to Finn, poor man!"

sentence1: for what would become of us all if anything happened to Finn, poor man!"
sentence2: She accordingly got the largest miscaun of butter she had--which might be about the weight of a couple of dozen millstones, so that you can easily judge of its size--and calling up her sister, "Granua," says she, "are you ready?

sentence1: She accordingly got the largest miscaun of butter she had--which might be about the weight of a couple of dozen millstones, so that you can easily judge of its size--and calling up her sister, "Granua," says she, "are you ready?

sentence2: Oonagh threw it, but in consequence of her anxiety about Finn and Far Rua she forgot to say the charm that was to send it up, so that instead of reaching Cullamore, as she expected, it fell about half-way between the two hills at the edge of the Broad Bog, near Augher.

sentence2: But, above all things, think of some plan to get Finn out of the scrape he's in, or he's a lost man.

sentence2: She then made a high smoke on the top of the hill, after which she put her finger in her mouth and gave three whistles, and by that Far Rua knew that he was invited to the top of Cullamore--for this was the way that the Irish long ago gave a sign to all strangers and travellers to let them know they are welcome to come and take share of whatever was going.

sentence2: In the meantime Finn was very melancholy, and did not know what to do, or how to act at all.

sentence1: In the meantime Finn was very melancholy, and did not know what to do, or how to act at all.
sentence2: What chance could he have, strong and brave as he was, with a man who could, when put in a passion, walk the country into earthquakes and knock thunderbolts into pancakes?

sentence1: What chance could he have, strong and brave as he was, with a man who could, when put in a passion, walk the country into earthquakes and knock thunderbolts into pancakes?
sentence2: The thing was impossible, and Finn knew not on what hand to turn him.

sentence1: The thing was impossible, and Finn knew not on what hand to turn him.
sentence2: Right or left, backward or forward, where to go he could form no guess whatever.

sentence1: Right or left, backward or forward, where to go he could form no guess whatever.
sentence2: "Oonagh," said he, "can you do anything for me?

sentence1: "Oonagh," said he, "can you do anything for me?
sentence2: Am I to be skivered like a rabbit before your eyes and to have my name disgraced for ever in the sight of all my tribe, and me the best man among them?

sentence1: "Be aisy, Finn," replied Oonagh.
sentence2: Talking of pancakes, maybe we'll give him as good as any he brings with him--thunderbolts or otherwise.

sentence1: Leave him to me, and do just as I bid you."

sentence2: Far Rua, at the moment, was not only hungry, but ravenous, so he accordingly made a fresh set at the second cake, and immediately another yell was heard twice as loud as the first.

sentence1: Far Rua, at the moment, was not only hungry, but ravenous, so he accordingly made a fresh set at the second cake, and immediately another yell was heard twice as loud as the first.
sentence2: he roared, "take your bread out of this, or I will not have a tooth in my head;

sentence1: he roared, "take your bread out of this, or I will not have a tooth in my head;
sentence2: "Well, honest man," replied Oonagh, "if you're not able to eat the bread say so quietly, and don't be awakening the child in the cradle there.

sentence1: "Well, honest man," replied Oonagh, "if you're not able to eat the bread say so quietly, and don't be awakening the child in the cradle there.
sentence2: Finn now gave a skirl that frightened the giant, as coming from such a youngster as he was represented to be.

sentence1: Finn now gave a skirl that frightened the giant, as coming from such a youngster as he was represented to be.
sentence2: "Mother," said he, "I'm hungry--get me something to eat."

sentence1: "Mother," said he, "I'm hungry--get me something to eat."
sentence2: Oonagh went over, and putting into his hand a cake that had no griddle in it--Finn, whose appetite in the meantime was sharpened by what he saw going forward, soon made it disappear.

sentence1: Oonagh went over, and putting into his hand a cake that had no griddle in it--Finn, whose appetite in the meantime was sharpened by what he saw going forward, soon made it disappear.
sentence2: Far Rua was thunderstruck, and secretly thanked his stars that he had the good fortune to miss meeting Finn, for, as he said to himself, I'd have no chance with a man who could eat such bread as that, which even his son that's in the cradle can munch before my eyes.

sentence1: Far Rua was thunderstruck, and secretly thanked his stars that he had the good fortune to miss meeting Finn, for, as he said to himself, I'd have no chance with a man who could eat such bread as that, which even his son that's in the cradle can munch before my eyes.
sentence2: "I'd like to take a glimpse at the lad in the cradle," said he to Oonagh, "for I can tell you that the infant who can manage that nutriment is no joke to look at or to feed of a scarce summer."

sentence1: "I'd like to take a glimpse at the lad in the cradle," said he to Oonagh, "for I can tell you that the infant who can manage that nutriment is no joke to look at or to feed of a scarce summer."
sentence2: "With all the veins of my heart," replied Oonagh.

sentence1: "With all the veins of my heart," replied Oonagh.
sentence2: "Get up, acushla, and show this decent little man something that won't be unworthy of your father, Finn M'Coul."

sentence1: "Get up, acushla, and show this decent little man something that won't be unworthy of your father, Finn M'Coul."
sentence2: Finn, who was dressed for the occasion as much like a boy as possible, got up, and bringing Far Rua out, "Are you strong?"

sentence1: Finn, who was dressed for the occasion as much like a boy as possible, got up, and bringing Far Rua out, "Are you strong?"
sentence2: exclaimed the other, "what a voice in so small a chap!"

sentence1: exclaimed the other, "what a voice in so small a chap!"
sentence2: said Finn again.

sentence1: said Finn again.
sentence2: "Are you able to squeeze water out of that white stone?"

sentence1: "Are you able to squeeze water out of that white stone?"
sentence2: he asked, putting one into Far Rua's hand.

sentence1: he asked, putting one into Far Rua's hand.
sentence2: The latter squeezed and squeezed the stone, but to no purpose;

sentence1: The latter squeezed and squeezed the stone, but to no purpose;
sentence2: he might pull the rocks of Lumford's Glen asunder, and flatten a thunderbolt, but to squeeze water out of a white stone was beyond his strength.

sentence1: he might pull the rocks of Lumford's Glen asunder, and flatten a thunderbolt, but to squeeze water out of a white stone was beyond his strength.
sentence2: Finn eyed him with great contempt as he kept straining and squeezing and squeezing and straining till he got black in the face with the efforts.

sentence1: Finn eyed him with great contempt as he kept straining and squeezing and squeezing and straining till he got black in the face with the efforts.
sentence2: "Ah, you're a poor creature," said Finn.

sentence1: "Ah, you're a poor creature," said Finn.
sentence2: Give me the stone here, and when I'll show what Finn's little son can do you may then judge of what my daddy himself is."

sentence1: Give me the stone here, and when I'll show what Finn's little son can do you may then judge of what my daddy himself is."
sentence2: Finn then took the stone, and then, slyly exchanging it for the curds, he squeezed the latter until the whey, as clear as water, oozed out in a little shower from his hand.

sentence1: Finn then took the stone, and then, slyly exchanging it for the curds, he squeezed the latter until the whey, as clear as water, oozed out in a little shower from his hand.
sentence2: "I'll now go in," said he, "to my cradle;

sentence1: "I'll now go in," said he, "to my cradle;
sentence2: for I scorn to lose my time with anyone that's not able to eat my daddy's bread, or squeeze water out of a stone.

sentence1: for I scorn to lose my time with anyone that's not able to eat my daddy's bread, or squeeze water out of a stone.
sentence2: Bedad, you had better be off out of this before he comes back, for if he catches you, it's in flummery he'd have you in two minutes."

sentence1: Bedad, you had better be off out of this before he comes back, for if he catches you, it's in flummery he'd have you in two minutes."
sentence2: Far Rua, seeing what he had seen, was of the same opinion himself;

sentence1: Far Rua, seeing what he had seen, was of the same opinion himself;
sentence2: his knees knocked together with the terror of Finn's return, and he accordingly hastened in to bid Oonagh farewell, and to assure her that, from that day out, he never wished to hear of, much less to see, her husband.

sentence1: his knees knocked together with the terror of Finn's return, and he accordingly hastened in to bid Oonagh farewell, and to assure her that, from that day out, he never wished to hear of, much less to see, her husband.
sentence2: "I admit fairly that I'm not a match for him," said he, "strong as I am.

sentence1: "I admit fairly that I'm not a match for him," said he, "strong as I am.
sentence2: Tell him I will avoid him as I would the plague, and that I will make myself scarce in this part of the country while I live."

sentence1: Tell him I will avoid him as I would the plague, and that I will make myself scarce in this part of the country while I live."
sentence2: Finn, in the meantime, had gone into the cradle, where he lay very quietly, his heart in his mouth with delight that Far Rua was about to take his departure without discovering the tricks that been played off on him.

sentence1: Finn, in the meantime, had gone into the cradle, where he lay very quietly, his heart in his mouth with delight that Far Rua was about to take his departure without discovering the tricks that been played off on him.
sentence2: "It's well for you," said Oonagh, "that he doesn't happen to be here, for it's nothing but hawk's meat he'd make of you."

sentence1: "It's well for you," said Oonagh, "that he doesn't happen to be here, for it's nothing but hawk's meat he'd make of you."
sentence2: "I know that," said Far Rua, "divel a thing else he'd make of me;

sentence1: "I know that," said Far Rua, "divel a thing else he'd make of me;
sentence2: but, before I go, will you let me feel what kind of teeth they are that can eat griddle-cakes like that?"

sentence1: but, before I go, will you let me feel what kind of teeth they are that can eat griddle-cakes like that?"
sentence2: and he pointed to it as he spoke.

sentence1: and he pointed to it as he spoke.
sentence2: "only as they're far back in his head you must put your finger a good way in."

sentence1: "only as they're far back in his head you must put your finger a good way in."
sentence2: Far Rua was surprised to find so powerful a set of grinders in one so young;

sentence1: Far Rua was surprised to find so powerful a set of grinders in one so young;
sentence2: but he was still much more so on finding, when he took his hand from Finn's mouth, that he had left the very finger upon which his whole strength depended behind him.

sentence1: but he was still much more so on finding, when he took his hand from Finn's mouth, that he had left the very finger upon which his whole strength depended behind him.
sentence2: He gave one loud groan and fell down at once with terror and weakness.

sentence1: He gave one loud groan and fell down at once with terror and weakness.
sentence2: This was all Finn wanted, who now knew that his most powerful and bitterest enemy was completely at his mercy.

sentence1: This was all Finn wanted, who now knew that his most powerful and bitterest enemy was completely at his mercy.
sentence2: He instantly started out of the cradle, and in a few minutes the great Far Rua, that was for such a length of time the terror of him and all his followers, was no more.
